channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Society is failing the disabled and can do better - Chief Ombudsman
item.description: The Chief Ombudsman says a quantum leap is needed to achieve equal rights for people with disabilities.

item.title: Anne Tolley reflects on her work in politics as she bows out
item.description: Anne Tolley reflects on 34 "fantastic" years in politics, including reform for children in state care, police and trades training.

item.title: More than 150 Island Bay homes lose power
item.description: Wellington power cuts have affected more than 200 homes this evening.

item.title: Clyde power outage on coldest day since 1978 prompts calls for review
item.description: "I had visited elderly people in Clyde that morning and saw for myself the difficulty some were having in keeping themselves warm," Mayor Tim Cadogan says.

item.title: Physical APEC cancellation 'a blow' to Auckland and NZ - business chamber
item.description: It will be difficult to leverage any real economic gains from a virtual APEC, Auckland's Business Chamber says.

item.title: Meridian spilled water to hike electricity prices - Authority ruling
item.description: The Electricity Authority has found that generator Meridian Energy manipulated the power market, costing consumers about $80 million.

item.title: Beachfront residents left in the dark over erosion plan
item.description: Wainui residents say they feel left in the dark over Gisborne District Council's management of erosion at the beachside settlement.

item.title: Odeon Theatre heritage property up for auction, needs restoration
item.description: A historic Christchurch theatre and neighbouring properties are set to go under the hammer in August.

item.title: Team NZ spying claims a new spin on America's Cup controversies
item.description: Not for the first time in its long history, the America's Cup is embroiled in skulduggery and subterfuge.

item.title: Website launches in Taranaki for casual work jobseekers
item.description: People searching for work in Taranaki have been offered a new platform to help find employment.

item.title: Council debate goes off the rails on pedestrianisation semantics
item.description: The politics of pedestrianisation has meant Dunedin City Council's straightforward plan to trial non-vehicular zones was never going to be simple.

item.title: Rock bottom crossbred wool prices pose dilemma for farmers
item.description: Crossbred wool prices have plummeted to new record low levels in the wake of Covid-19, with some farmers receiving less than a dollar a kilogram for their wool.

item.title: Covid-19: No new cases in New Zealand
item.description: There are no new cases of Covid-19 in the country to report today, the Ministry of Health says.

item.title: Schools opting for group starts over Kiwi tradition
item.description: Ministry of Education figures show 101 schools have dropped the Kiwi tradition of letting children start school on their fifth birthday - opting instead for "cohort entry".

item.title: Weather: Chilly morning, snow on the way
item.description: Snow is on the way for alpine passes in the South Island and parts of the central North Island.

item.title: After rumoured sightings, rare NZ long-tailed bat heard in Masterton
item.description: After many years of rumoured sightings in regions, a rare long-tailed bat has been heard for the first time in Masterton.

item.title: Police failed in duty of care to detainee who died - IPCA
item.description: Police failed in their duty of care to a man who attempted suicide in a court cell and later died in hospital, the Independent Police Conduct Authority has found.

item.title: Juniper hunt seedlings could grow NZs first gin berry plantation
item.description: New Zealand is one step closer to establishing the country's first plantation of Juniperus communis - whose berries are the key ingredient of gin - following a nationwide search for the elusive conifer.
